<p><strong>There is a significant opportunity</strong> to increase inclusive growth in America by closing persistent racial gaps in educational opportunities and achievement. Eliminating these gaps could help reverse downward trends in social mobility while potentially generating up to $700 billion in additional GDP for the nation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1d8a63fd-3264-4246-b8a3-75e683631c35"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1d8a63fd-3264-4246-b8a3-75e683631c35" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis has estimated that had the Black and Hispanic student-achievement gap been closed in 2009, the US GDP in 2019 would have been $426 billion to $705 billion higher. For more, see Emma Dorn, Bryan Hancock, Jimmy Sarakatsannis, and Ellen Viruleg, “<a href="/industries/education/our-insights/covid-19-and-student-learning-in-the-united-states-the-hurt-could-last-a-lifetime">COVID-19 and student learning in the United States: The hurt could last a lifetime</a>,” McKinsey, June 1, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> And there are resources available to jump-start initiatives. The Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief Fund (ESSER) allocated $190 billion in federal funding to the nation’s schools, from prekindergarten (pre-K) to 12th grade—a resource pool that could be used to advance racial-equity investments in education. But the clock is ticking: the funds must be obligated by September 2024.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5e3ef7d5-adb8-46b0-83ef-35422b131fe6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5e3ef7d5-adb8-46b0-83ef-35422b131fe6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/industries/education/our-insights/halftime-for-the-k-12-stimulus-how-are-districts-faring">Halftime for the K–12 stimulus: How are districts faring?</a>,” McKinsey, November 2, 2022; ESSER received funds under three COVID-19 relief packages passed by Congress: the Coronavirus Aid, Relief and Economic Security Act; the Coronavirus Response and Relief Supplemental Appropriations Act; and the American Rescue Plan. For more, see “Monitoring and reporting,” Office of Elementary & Secondary Education, last updated June 14, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

and the McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Based on detailed reviews of research and case studies, we have identified six actions that leaders of school systems and their communities could take to use the remaining ESSER funding to advance racial equity in education (exhibit).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cf2550da-ba6d-419f-b44c-b41eb0941ebc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cf2550da-ba6d-419f-b44c-b41eb0941ebc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">We use the term “school systems” throughout this article to refer to both districts and charters because we believe that many of these proposed interventions are important for a full community of schools to consider together, regardless of governance.</span></span></span></a></span> While this list is not exhaustive, these select areas include those in which students of color may have less access, lower quality, or fewer resources. Some of these solutions may not be novel, but our experience has shown that consistent implementation of these actions, and implementation at scale, has been a challenge thus far.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/education/our%20insights/advancing%20racial%20equity%20in%20us%20pre%20k%2012%20education/svgz-racialequity-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Six actions could advance racial equity." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/education/our%20insights/advancing%20racial%20equity%20in%20us%20pre%20k%2012%20education/svgz-racialequity-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>To be clear, these actions, even if taken at scale, may not eliminate racial disparities in pre-K–12 education. However, evidence suggests that these investments could help shift current trajectories for education opportunities and outcomes, generating meaningful advances in equity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="36874d81-d2ad-4610-aa90-4b17295c8ca9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="36874d81-d2ad-4610-aa90-4b17295c8ca9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Many other interventions with rigorous evaluation have improved student outcomes (such as extracurriculars and changes to discipline systems), but in this article, we focus on those with evidence of successful interventions at scale.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>The persistent opportunity and achievement gap</h2>
<p>The opportunity gap in public education between White students and students of color has persisted throughout our nation’s history. When free public education began to spread in the early 19th century, children of color were often excluded. When they did gain access, they were often segregated and underserved.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="761a8f61-daef-403d-9cf6-9843388550c5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="761a8f61-daef-403d-9cf6-9843388550c5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“History and evolution of public education in the US,” Center on Education Policy, 2020; Colette Coleman, “How literacy became a powerful weapon in the fight to end slavery,” History.com, January 29, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Forced segregation was permissible until the Brown v. Board of Education Supreme Court decision in 1954, and despite decades of court-ordered desegregation that followed, 98 percent of Black children in the South still attended segregated schools in 1964.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="038b903d-ddfc-41b8-9e1b-8938446abd30"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="038b903d-ddfc-41b8-9e1b-8938446abd30" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Brown v. Board of Education,” <em>Journal of American History</em>, June 2004, Volume 91, Number 1.</span></span></span></a></span> And children of color were often forced to attend segregated schools with a focus on assimilation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c1be09c8-2435-4d66-b1cb-0885965c7166"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c1be09c8-2435-4d66-b1cb-0885965c7166" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“San Francisco Public Schools deny admission to Chinese-American children,” Equal Justice Initiative, accessed June 27, 2023; “‘Cultural genocide’ and Native American children,” Equal Justice Initiative, September 1, 2014.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Since the 1970s,</strong> progress has been made to narrow racial inequities in outcomes <p>However, meaningful progress in accelerating outcomes for students of color has stalled, leaving large gaps of roughly 0.6 to 0.8 standard deviations compared with White students.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="45a2c4c0-f45e-414f-ae8a-03141cc34f65"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="45a2c4c0-f45e-414f-ae8a-03141cc34f65" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Michael Hansen et al., “Have we made progress on achievement gaps? those of White students within the same districts, and the difference between Hispanic and White students’ average test scores in the same district is about 1.5 grades.<span <p>Moreover, because of the effects of the pandemic, those gaps have widened (exhibit).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f6a498e8-4711-45ee-9baa-7d4f8e08cc8b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f6a498e8-4711-45ee-9baa-7d4f8e08cc8b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Emma Dorn, Bryan Hancock, Jimmy Sarakatsannis, and Ellen Viruleg, “<a href="/industries/education/our-insights/covid-19-and-education-the-lingering-effects-of-unfinished-learning">COVID-19 and education: The lingering effects of unfinished learning</a>,” McKinsey, July 27, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> In majority-Black schools, students are five months behind their historical levels in both math and reading, on average. <p>Through the 1970s and ’80s, racial inequities in academic outcomes were closing, but there is still a long way to go. At the pace of change before the COVID-19 pandemic, it would take an estimated 60 to 160 years for students of color to achieve educational parity in the United States (see sidebar “Racial gaps in educational outcomes over time”).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8bb790c4-5208-43c8-b739-dd367d7e1a4f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8bb790c4-5208-43c8-b739-dd367d7e1a4f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis of “Racial and ethnic achievement gaps,” Education Opportunity Monitoring Project, Stanford Center for Education Policy Analysis, 2015.</span></span></span></a></span> And the pandemic, which wiped out two decades’ worth of math and reading progress for the nation’s fourth and eighth graders, exacerbated existing gaps.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bbb3fb0a-d266-47a4-b52d-38944aca5d08"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bbb3fb0a-d266-47a4-b52d-38944aca5d08" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sarah Mervosh, “The pandemic erased two decades of progress in math and reading,” <em>New York Times</em>, September 1, 2022; “<a href="/industries/education/our-insights/covid-19-and-education-the-lingering-effects-of-unfinished-learning">COVID-19 and education: The lingering effects of unfinished learning</a>,” McKinsey, July 27, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Declines in National Assessment of Education Progress (NAEP) math scores were much larger for Black students than for their White peers.</p>

<p>These developments, and the availability of federal funding to combat pandemic-related learning delays, offer an opportunity for action.</p>
<h2>Three actions school systems can take directly</h2>
<!-- -->
<p>Below are three actions school systems can control directly to help close equity gaps, as well as steps they could take to jump-start initiatives.</p>
<h3>1. Strengthen core early-literacy instructional practices</h3>
<p>Early literacy is closely linked to student success. Students who do not read proficiently by third grade are four times less likely to graduate from high school.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bf82ef3b-397b-4956-9839-e9fac03795a0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bf82ef3b-397b-4956-9839-e9fac03795a0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Double jeopardy: How third grade reading skills and poverty influence high school graduation</em>, Annie E. Casey Foundation, January 1, 2012.</span></span></span></a></span> While strong literacy instruction benefits all students, it could have an outsize impact on closing racial gaps. Struggling readers are disproportionately students of color; for example, of the one million fourth graders who do not read at a proficient level, two-thirds are Black or Hispanic.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="28d57274-ab4a-4db9-8e4a-6c3e4b5a5c39"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="28d57274-ab4a-4db9-8e4a-6c3e4b5a5c39" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Teacher prep review: Program performance in early reading instruction</em>, National Council on Teacher Quality (NCTQ), January 2020 (a count by the NCTQ of students who scored “below basic” on the reading assessment in 2019).</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Research on tens of thousands of children and adults summarized by the National Center on Teacher Quality (NCTQ) provides a road map to potentially reduce the rate of reading failure from three in ten children to one in ten.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="642a81a0-57e4-496d-b06d-453a661b540b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="642a81a0-57e4-496d-b06d-453a661b540b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Teacher prep review: Program performance in early reading instruction</em>, National Council on Teacher Quality (NCTQ), January 2020 (a count by the NCTQ of students who scored “below basic” on the reading assessment in 2019).</span></span></span></a></span> This road map includes a strong phonics curriculum and intervention, paired with vocabulary and background knowledge gleaned from broad exposure to varied content.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c61ca428-5c56-4d9a-8326-c2ebe3228cd1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c61ca428-5c56-4d9a-8326-c2ebe3228cd1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Narrowing the third-grade reading gap</em>, EAB, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> School systems have achieved significant growth in early-literacy results by implementing research-backed actions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="94783d22-d34e-45f4-86e1-347fc13451c0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="94783d22-d34e-45f4-86e1-347fc13451c0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Narrowing the third-grade reading gap</em>, EAB, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Starting in 2013, Mississippi passed a series of state laws that overhauled the state’s approach to teaching reading, aligning it with research-backed literacy practices. Between 2017 and 2019, it was the only state to see fourth-grade literacy gains on the NAEP, with Black students’ scores improving at a faster pace than those of their White peers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d713aacc-69b9-42e7-966a-fbd0f6b61716"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d713aacc-69b9-42e7-966a-fbd0f6b61716" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Liana Loewus, “National reading scores are down. What does it mean?,” <em>Education Week</em>, October 30, 2019; Tim Abram and Kymyona Burk, “#AskExcelinEd: What is the state of Black education in Mississippi?,” ExcelinEd, April 14, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Other states are now following a similar strategy: in 2021, Louisiana proposed investments and passed legislation focused on early literacy, and in 2020, Tennessee passed legislation focused on foundational literacy skills.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e7cd0cd7-597c-4c22-be2d-870a30d002cd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e7cd0cd7-597c-4c22-be2d-870a30d002cd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Louisiana governor Edwards signs big and bold early literacy legislation,” ExcelinEd, June 23, 2021; Marta W. Aldrich, “Literacy bill on the move in Tennessee Legislature, minus the phrase ‘science of reading,’” <em>Chalkbeat Tennessee</em>, March 10, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p><strong><em>Getting started.</em></strong> ESSER investments can help jump-start efforts to strengthen approaches to early-literacy instruction. To ensure those funds deliver maximum impact, system leaders could start by assessing the degree to which current literacy practices are backed by research. This could lead to curricular changes, new approaches to professional development, or other adjustments that could strengthen literacy instruction for students of color. States could also consider taking on a stronger role in overseeing teacher prep programs, which are currently largely outside their purview; requiring professional development that is aligned with curriculums and research; and publishing standards for state-approved curriculums and assessments.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8f34f4bf-fc31-43a3-9901-2a86501f89e8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8f34f4bf-fc31-43a3-9901-2a86501f89e8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">As of June 2023, 31 states and Washington, DC, have passed laws or implemented policies focused on the science of reading. Eighteen mention teacher prep, and 16 address teacher certification or license renewal. For more, see Sarah Schwartz, “Which states have passed ‘science of reading’ laws? What’s in them?,” <em>Education Week</em>, May 9, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>2. Use an equity framework to allocate resources</h3>
<p>Resources such as staff, time, and money are limited and often concentrated on students from wealthier (usually White) families.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6a3a1a8b-1ead-44f9-86e9-1db9be9fd5f0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6a3a1a8b-1ead-44f9-86e9-1db9be9fd5f0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>$23 billion</em>, EdBuild, February 2019; Dan Goldhaber and Michael Hansen, “National board certification and teachers’ career path: Does NBPTS certification influence how long teachers remain in the profession and where they teach?,” <em>Education Finance and Policy</em>, 2009, Volume 4, Number 3; Charles T. Clotfelter, Helen F. Ladd, and Jacob Vigdor, “Who teaches whom? Race and the distribution of novice teachers,” <em>Economics of Education Review</em>, August 2005, Volume 24, Number 4.</span></span></span></a></span> Nationally, historically underserved students receive between $400 and $1,200 less per pupil than White and economically advantaged students.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5e6755d4-2fc7-46de-accb-ad6fcea26030"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5e6755d4-2fc7-46de-accb-ad6fcea26030" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Hojung Lee, Kenneth A. <p><strong><em>Getting started.</em></strong> System leaders could start by assessing whether resources are allocated with equity of opportunity in mind. This includes examining the distribution of the most effective staff, the impact of instructional and operational vacancies, facilities equity, per-pupil spend, and shared central resources. An equity framework could inform conversations about the best ways to allocate high-quality teachers and leaders to schools where they can have the greatest impact as well as other strategies to shift resources to ensure equity of opportunity.</p>
<h3>3. Increase instructional time for students who need it the most</h3>
<p>Research indicates tutoring can have a significant impact on student learning at scale,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="39a0a547-6c62-42b8-b740-a3ac57e04f0c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="39a0a547-6c62-42b8-b740-a3ac57e04f0c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Matthew A. Kraft et al., “Accelerating student learning with high-dosage tutoring,” Annenberg Institute at Brown University, February 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> making it a potentially effective approach for combating pandemic-related learning loss to advance racial equity in education. A study by the University of Chicago found that individualized, intensive (“high dosage”) tutoring could more than double the amount of math students learned in a single academic year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9bcde831-fc85-43ed-9287-58df04cc34f1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9bcde831-fc85-43ed-9287-58df04cc34f1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">High-dosage tutoring consisted of daily 45- to 50-minute two-on-one math instruction for ninth and tenth graders; Monica P. <p>School systems can explore many tutoring programs, such as Saga Education, Reading Partners, and the Minnesota Math Corps.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="169f177a-fda5-42fd-9a05-6bea6949db4c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">34</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="169f177a-fda5-42fd-9a05-6bea6949db4c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Accelerating student learning with high-dosage tutoring,” February 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> As school systems work to establish these programs, state leaders could also help by providing dedicated funding and technical assistance. <p><strong><em>Getting started.</em></strong> ESSER resources provide an opportunity to increase instructional time for students of color who need additional support. State leaders could consider replicating efforts like Tennessee’s to provide incentives for and build momentum around high-dosage tutoring.</p>
<h2>Three actions that require broad community leadership</h2>
<p>Advancing racial equity in education also means addressing factors that are outside of school systems’ direct control. To help close gaps in education opportunity and outcomes, community leaders could take the following three actions in partnership with school system leaders.</p>
<h3>1. Ensure access to high-quality pre-K</h3>
<p>Research shows that children enrolled in pre-K programs typically go on to achieve higher test scores and better language development. Often, they also have better attendance and fewer behavioral problems in school.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="97dc7439-4d93-4eaa-8351-0b33df1d1b4f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">36</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="97dc7439-4d93-4eaa-8351-0b33df1d1b4f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Craig S. Burchinal et al., “Puzzling it out: The current state of scientific knowledge on pre-kindergarten effects,” Brookings Institution, April 17, 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> Research suggests that attending a high-quality pre-K program can close as much as 50 percent of the racial achievement gap.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e8f31259-310e-47c2-8eca-b4ca1bb42eed"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">38</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e8f31259-310e-47c2-8eca-b4ca1bb42eed" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">W. <p>But racial disparities exist today in both enrollment and access to high-quality programming.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5ef6be26-37e1-4045-b255-6f55bd9c1fe6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">39</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5ef6be26-37e1-4045-b255-6f55bd9c1fe6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">While 43 percent of White three- and four-year-olds were enrolled in either public or private preschool in 2020, only 33 percent of Hispanic children were enrolled. For more, see “Enrollment rates of young children,” NCES, last updated May 2023; American Community Survey 2010–19 data, US Census Bureau; and Jonathan T. Rothwell, “Classroom inequality and the cognitive race gap: Evidence from 4-year-olds in public preK,” Social Science Research Network, March 2, 2016.</span></span></span></a></span> To reduce these gaps, school systems could consider investing in high-quality pre-K and ensuring access for children of color.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ea25f174-e205-4f1a-965f-514ab468f72a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">40</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ea25f174-e205-4f1a-965f-514ab468f72a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jake Bryant, Emmy Liss, Jimmy Sarakatsannis, and Ellen Viruleg, “<a href="/industries/education/our-insights/expanding-publicly-funded-pre-k-how-to-do-it-and-do-it-well">Expanding publicly funded pre-K: How to do it and do it well</a>,” McKinsey, January 13, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p><strong><em>How school system leaders can support community pre-K efforts.</em></strong> School systems could convene state and local leaders, district and charter leaders, childcare providers, parents, advocates, workforce partners, and others to develop a road map to expand high-quality pre-K with a focus on racial equity. And if doing so requires a new revenue source, the assembled stakeholders could help build a coalition to identify potential funding mechanisms. Some states and localities have used short-term federal funds to pilot expanded pre-K programs, though other funding sources will likely be needed to ensure long-term sustainability.</p>
<h3>2. Provide wraparound services for families and communities</h3>
<p>Factors that affect long-term outcomes for youth, such as stable affordable housing and exposure to traumatic events, are beyond the direct control of the school system. Children who have experienced a single adverse childhood experience earn 7.3 percent less than their peers and are more likely to depend on public benefits and live in poverty.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="793fa8a7-758b-4534-a43b-78e859f278dd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">41</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="793fa8a7-758b-4534-a43b-78e859f278dd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Examples of adverse childhood experiences include violence, abuse, or exposure to substance use problems; Stefanie Schurer and Kristian Trajkovski, <em>Understanding the mechanisms through which adverse childhood experiences affect lifetime economic outcomes</em>, IZA Institute of Labor Economics working paper, Discussion Paper Series, number 11450, April 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> Wraparound healthcare, social services, and other supports are thus considered critical complements to a strong school. This is particularly important for students of color. McKinsey research has found that many Black neighborhoods are consumer deserts, with inadequate access to food, affordable housing, healthcare services, broadband, and banks.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6f4a4e8a-fc42-4107-aa05-36fc0338b706"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">42</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6f4a4e8a-fc42-4107-aa05-36fc0338b706" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be">The economic state of Black America: What is and what could be</a>,” McKinsey, June 17, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Harlem Children’s Zone (HCZ) provides an example of what can be achieved by combining strong schools with effective community support. Educator Geoffrey Canada created HCZ in 1997 to address challenges children in Harlem were facing through what HCZ calls “cradle-to-career services” centered on education,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ac868e42-40d1-428e-a43b-18119523185f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">43</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ac868e42-40d1-428e-a43b-18119523185f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“History of Harlem Children’s Zone,” Harlem Children’s Zone, accessed June 28, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> including parent workshops, full-day preschool, health clinics, youth violence prevention efforts, and college admissions support. HCZ played a central role in connecting services across schools, local government, and community organizations. HCZ’s work was credited with eliminating gaps in outcomes between students of color and White students in both literacy and math.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3627ffc5-dfc2-4c4e-a692-af478cd2796b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">44</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3627ffc5-dfc2-4c4e-a692-af478cd2796b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Will Dobbie and Roland G. Fryer, Jr., “Are high-quality schools enough to increase achievement among the poor? Evidence from the Harlem Children’s Zone,” <em>American Economic Journal: Applied Economics</em>, July 2011, Volume 3, Number 3.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Numerous efforts have been made to replicate HCZ’s success, including through the Obama administration’s Promise Neighborhoods initiative. Launched in 2010, the initiative has awarded grants to 17 cities, but results have been mixed—an outcome some researchers say highlights the difficulty of measuring success and shows how varied needs can be from one community to another.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f29806e4-e3ef-42c8-8161-02ddaf06d359"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">45</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f29806e4-e3ef-42c8-8161-02ddaf06d359" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The need for a long-term horizon is just one of the reasons identified for the mixed results; this work is transformational and requires significant shifts across the community. Another reason is funding: the economic recession beginning in 2008 meant that the Promise Neighborhoods program was funded at far lower levels than intended. For the HCZ, Geoffrey Canada played the role of the link among schools, local government, and community organizations. Civic leaders stepping into a leadership role to connect these components of a community is critical for successful replication. For more, see Amadou Diallo, “As Harlem Children’s Zone moves to export its model nationwide, other city programs offer cautionary tales,” <em>Washington Post</em>, December 21, 2020; and Amanda Erickson, “Why hasn’t the Harlem Children’s Zone been replicated even without Obama’s help?,” Bloomberg, August 16, 2012.</span></span></span></a></span> In Buffalo, the Say Yes to Education program saw graduation rates climb 15 points from 2012 (the starting year of operations) to 2017. The program includes the promise of free college tuition for graduates and provides a full suite of wraparound services for students. Leaders highlight cooperation from local government, schools, the teachers’ union, parents, business groups, and higher education as instrumental to Buffalo’s success.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d1f0ac2d-845d-4f93-ac38-7a00a78a0415"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">46</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d1f0ac2d-845d-4f93-ac38-7a00a78a0415" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Amadou Diallo, “Buffalo shows turnaround of urban schools is possible, but it takes a lot more than just money,” <em>Hechinger Report</em>, July 18, 2017.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The Dudley Street Neighborhood Initiative (DSNI) in Boston is another example of a neighborhood collaborative that has supported community-led initiatives to increase affordable housing and strengthen community infrastructure.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="63181fc4-3de5-4eb3-8dec-565b1db425a4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">47</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="63181fc4-3de5-4eb3-8dec-565b1db425a4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lee Allen Dwyer, <em>Mapping impact: An analysis of the Dudley Street Neighborhood Initiative land trust</em>, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, June 2015; “Boston Promise Initiative at Dudley Street Neighborhood Initiative,” Promise Neighborhoods Institute, 2014.</span></span></span></a></span> HCZ, the Say Yes program, and DSNI have relied on partnerships with a broad base of funders that have made long-term commitments.</p>
<p><strong><em>How school systems can support wraparound services and support.</em></strong> School systems with large populations of students of color living in neighborhoods that are consumer deserts could begin by identifying a leader who can build a community and school system coalition organized around long-term collaborative commitments to strengthen the community. As the coalition builds momentum, its focus could turn to ensuring sufficient funding over the long term.</p>
<h3>3. Address school racial, ethnic, and economic divisions</h3>
<p>Longitudinal studies of court-ordered desegregation in the 1950s and 1960s found that five years in an integrated school environment translated into a 14.5-percentage-point increase in the likelihood of Black students graduating from high school.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5d748bdf-3c49-4829-86c2-b539ae035da1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">48</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5d748bdf-3c49-4829-86c2-b539ae035da1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Rucker C. Johnson, <em>Long-run impacts of school desegregation & school quality on adult attainments</em>, National Bureau Economic Research (NBER) Working Paper Series, number 16664, January 2011.</span></span></span></a></span> More recently, an analysis of NAEP results showed that low-income students in high-poverty schools were about two years of learning behind low-income students attending more-affluent schools.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="671396b2-8a58-46b6-9715-b9fd3abb5985"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">49</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="671396b2-8a58-46b6-9715-b9fd3abb5985" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“The benefits of socioeconomically and racially integrated schools and classrooms,” Century Foundation, April 29, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> And it’s not just historically marginalized students who benefit from attending more-affluent schools (which tend to have a higher proportion of White students than low-income schools do): students of all races and socioeconomic statuses show improvements in critical thinking, motivation, creativity, and problem-solving skills in socioeconomically diverse classrooms.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a49d30bc-7df8-41e0-acfa-040c376e7762"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">50</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span Foundation, April 29, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Yet nearly 70 years after Brown v. Board of Education, the nation’s schools remain divided along racial, ethnic, and economic lines, despite student populations becoming increasingly diverse.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="824423b7-9be1-4b19-92be-b92cae43ba38"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">51</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="824423b7-9be1-4b19-92be-b92cae43ba38" class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" <p>Some schools and communities around the country are trying to address this issue by focusing on socioeconomic integration.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7f37ee0c-cfce-487a-8daa-aef9ae3c7db3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">54</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7f37ee0c-cfce-487a-8daa-aef9ae3c7db3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">This has potentially been a strategic pivot after multiple voluntary racial-integration efforts were dismantled by the Supreme Court in the early

<p>In Dallas and San Antonio, school district leaders worked with communities to identify new school models that would be compelling to parents across all socioeconomic groups, such as science, technology, engineering, arts, and math (STEAM) programs; dual-language schools; and advanced-learning opportunities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="35493353-b11c-454b-af99-965d0577f33c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">56</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="35493353-b11c-454b-af99-965d0577f33c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For Dallas, see Carole Learned-Miller, <em>Dallas Independent School District: Integration as innovation</em>, Century Foundation, October 14, 2016; class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Case studies in socioeconomic integration</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Across the United States,</strong> school systems and communities are focusing on socioeconomics in an effort to diversify schools. Case studies of Dallas, San Antonio, and New York City show a variety of ways to address the issue.</p>
<h4>Dallas, Texas</h4>
<p>In Dallas, racial segregation and concentrated poverty have traditionally gone hand in hand, limiting resources and supports for schools in communities of color.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="38ed5d4f-9f2f-4dcc-a909-09354584b58f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="38ed5d4f-9f2f-4dcc-a909-09354584b58f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kate Rix, “How Dallas is reversing decades of white flight from its school system,” <em>Guardian</em>, August 4, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Starting in 2014, the city opened some new schools and transformed others to include options that families indicated would be more appealing. The city put new admissions policies in place at these new schools, reserving half of the slots for students from one of the city’s economically disadvantaged communities and half for students from more-affluent communities. Transportation was provided to mitigate barriers to attendance.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bc4a1ac1-a4a1-411c-a2ca-0b431d07effc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bc4a1ac1-a4a1-411c-a2ca-0b431d07effc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Carole Learned-Miller, <em>Dallas Independent School District: Integration as innovation</em>, Century Foundation, October 14, 2016</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Examples are emerging of newer schools that are far more representative of Dallas’s overall population, both racially and socioeconomically, than the average Dallas public school.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a7cefc8f-1e89-4637-ae69-690ad7f79b09"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a7cefc8f-1e89-4637-ae69-690ad7f79b09" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Carole Learned-Miller, <em>Dallas Independent School District: Integration as innovation</em>, Century Foundation, October 14, 2016</span></span></span></a></span> But the benefits extend beyond just school composition: the “diverse by design” schools have stronger student attendance and teacher retention than average and are increasingly popular with families.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b720f7ba-d8b9-47d7-9e0a-4fce6c6b6259"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b720f7ba-d8b9-47d7-9e0a-4fce6c6b6259" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kate Rix, “How Dallas is reversing decades of white flight from its school system,” <em>Guardian</em>, August 4, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h4>San Antonio, Texas</h4>
<p>In San Antonio, the lowest-performing schools were often located in the city’s highest-poverty communities. When city leaders first considered how to better support the most vulnerable students, they started with granular data analysis, mapping indicators of poverty on a block-by-block basis. Using this data, leaders sorted students into four socioeconomic groups (called “blocks”) based on the level of disadvantage they were facing. Then, as the district opened new schools in 2017 with attractive magnet programs, leaders intentionally set aside seats for students from all four blocks, particularly focusing on the students in Block Four—those with the greatest economic hurdles.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="71efb435-8012-4ab9-b866-fa53e142f67c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="71efb435-8012-4ab9-b866-fa53e142f67c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Beth Hawkins, “78207: America’s most radical school integration experiment,” <em>The 74</em>, September 25, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>San Antonio paired the rollout of its integration program with an initiative to bring strong educators to historically low-performing schools. With these two efforts combined, the number of students in schools deemed failing by the state dropped by 400 percent, and in 2018, San Antonio was considered the fastest-improving school system in Texas.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8db6414a-402b-4690-a3f3-ff9e04831958"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8db6414a-402b-4690-a3f3-ff9e04831958" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Beth Hawkins, “78207: America’s most radical school integration experiment,” <em>The 74</em>, September 25, 2018; Mohammed Choudhury, “It’s still possible to take action on school segregation. Here’s how we’re doing it in San Antonio,” <em>Chalkbeat</em>, August 1, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h4>New York City’s District 15</h4>
<p>New York City’s District 15 served a socioeconomically and racially diverse population within a relatively contiguous geographic area, but in very segregated schools. For years, community leaders and elected officials pushed for action on integration.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0ad058c1-3d9b-425b-8262-28f8b4a4b6bc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0ad058c1-3d9b-425b-8262-28f8b4a4b6bc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Abigail Savitch-Lew, “Ambitious Brooklyn school desegregation plan stirs excitements, faces hurdles,” CityLimits, July 9, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> A formal planning process finally kicked off in 2017, endorsed by the district but led by a working group of community members and supported by an external facilitator.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="07426f05-aa2f-4632-b227-56e338f9590d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="07426f05-aa2f-4632-b227-56e338f9590d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">From the D15 Diversity Plan.</span></span></span></a></span> Parents were invited to weigh in at public workshops and given meaningful support to participate, including real-time translation, travel vouchers, childcare, and food.</p>
<p>Under the plan the working group developed, which was then ratified by the New York City Department of Education, academic screening for middle school admissions in District 15 was eliminated, and all schools set aside more than half of seats for historically disadvantaged students. The working group also advocated for additional resources to ensure schools would be equitable and inclusive, including training for staff, changes to curriculums, and restorative-justice practices.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="79ef3abb-4654-4b5b-9900-e66c9685a1b1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="79ef3abb-4654-4b5b-9900-e66c9685a1b1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Mayor de Blasio and Chancellor Carranza announce District 15 middle school diversity plan and launch $2M school diversity grant program,” City of New York, September 20, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The new policy was implemented in 2018. By July 2020, economic segregation in sixth grade had decreased by 55 percent, while racial segregation decreased by 38 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8a982177-1092-4876-b58d-8f93018b9463"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8a982177-1092-4876-b58d-8f93018b9463" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Daniel Dench, Shirin Hashim, and Jesse Margolis, <em>The impact of middle school integration efforts on segregation in two New York City districts</em>, MarGrady Research, July 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> In the first year of the program, there was no discernable White flight; in fact, the overall racial composition of the district remained the same.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6970b6e5-8e20-4bdd-998e-94c5d31f909c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6970b6e5-8e20-4bdd-998e-94c5d31f909c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nyah Berg, Brad Lander, and David Tipson, “The white flight that wasn’t: New data reveal that Brooklyn school integration is working,” <em>New York Daily News</em>, November 14, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>In New York City’s District 15, a community school district encompassing affluent brownstone Brooklyn and lower-income and immigrant enclaves, a community-driven process led to a controlled-choice admissions plan for middle school. Since its launch in 2018, this plan has decreased economic and racial segregation (see sidebar “Case studies in socioeconomic integration”).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="69348a5a-79e4-4ed2-a5c7-c544fe2ed61c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">59</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="69348a5a-79e4-4ed2-a5c7-c544fe2ed61c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Daniel Dench, Shirin Hashim, and Jesse Margolis, <em>The impact of middle school integration efforts on segregation in two New York City districts</em>, MarGrady Research, July 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p><strong><em>How school systems can support integration efforts.</em></strong> The path forward for socioeconomic integration—and racial integration by proxy—often depends on local context and requires a long-term vision for implementation. System leaders could start by studying the enrollment and demographic patterns in their community to understand the challenge and the opportunity. They could then partner with local groups to understand what kind of change families might support and listen to perspectives from all stakeholders to build a coalition for change. Districts could use federal funds to spur planning and engagement efforts, which often require real resources to be successful and inclusive.</p>
<hr>
<p>The lack of meaningful progress in closing racial disparities in pre-K–12 educational outcomes, and the disproportionate impact the pandemic has had on learning for students of color, suggests that policy makers need to think differently about how to close these gaps. At the same time, collective community energy around addressing pandemic recovery and the resources provided by ESSER represent a unique opportunity for school system leaders to address racial inequities. To seize that opportunity, leaders could consider translating a vision for equity into meaningful actions such as the six described here, with broader community commitment for long-term initiatives.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/jacob-bryant">Jake Bryant</a></strong> is a partner in McKinsey’s Seattle office, <strong><a href="/our-people/duwain-pinder">Duwain Pinder</a></strong> is a partner in the Ohio office and a leader of the McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility, and <strong>Nina Yancy</strong> is a consultant in the New York office. <strong>Emmy Liss,</strong> who worked in the New York City Department of Education and was involved in the city’s socioeconomic integration efforts, and <strong>Greg Rawson</strong> are senior advisers to McKinsey’s Education Practice.</p>
